unnormalised: Manufacturing & Supply Chain: Quality Control Boost Vital for "Make in India" Success
normalised: Manufacturing and Supply Chain: Quality Control Boost Vital for "Make in India" Success

unnormalised: Experts at IIT-Delhi held a workshop on 14/07/2024, emphasizing the crucial role of robust quality control measures for Indian manufacturers aiming to compete globally under the "Make in India" initiative. The workshop highlighted the need for companies, especially SMEs in sectors like textiles from Tirupur and automotive components from Pune, to adopt international standards like ISO 9001.
normalised: Experts at I I T-Delhi held a workshop on fourteenth july two thousand and twenty four, emphasizing the crucial role of robust quality control measures for Indian manufacturers aiming to compete globally under the "Make in India" initiative. The workshop highlighted the need for companies, especially S M Es in sectors like textiles from Tirupur and automotive components from Pune, to adopt international standards like I S O nine thousand and one.

unnormalised: "Quality isn't just a checkpoint; it's a continuous process, a 'karma' if you will," stated Prof. Sharma during the 10:30 hrs session. He stressed the importance of statistical process control and Six Sigma methodologies. Implementing these tools, alongside regular audits, helps minimize defects and improve overall efficiency, saving companies potentially crores of rupees in rework and returns. The deadline for submitting the new quality control proposals is set for 31/08/2024. Improved quality also reduces supply chain disruptions and builds trust with both domestic and international buyers, ultimately strengthening India's manufacturing reputation.
